column1: Pemba is a port city in Mozambique. It is the capital of the province of Cabo Delgado and lies on a peninsula in Pemba Bay.
The town was founded by the Niassa Company in 1904 as Porto Amélia
column3: at the peninsula's southwestern tip and has grown around a port.  The city is renowned for its Portuguese colonial architecture. It was renamed Pemba at the end of Portuguese rule
column4: in 1975. The city's inhabitants are primarily Swahili

column1: Pemba has a tropical savanna climate (Köppen climate classification Aw). Temperatures fluctuate little throughout the year due to the city's tropical location and closeness to the equator. It has only two seasons. The wet season is from December to April and brings heavy but reliable rainfall
column2: the wettest month typically being March with an average rainfall of 202.2 mm (7.96 in). Conversely
column3: the dry season stretches from May to November and brings marginally cooler temperatures
column6: the driest month typically being September with an average rainfall of 2.2 mm (0.09 in). Humidity is very high during the wet season
